Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Exhumation of a High-Grade Metamorphic Terrane, and Late-Stage Orogenic Collapse in the Southeastern New England Appalachians
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Appalachians are a composite mountain belt consisting of various microcontinents, oceanic and continental volcanic arcs and (meta)sedimentary domains that collided during the Appalachian mountain building events. Geological investigations in the Appalachian commonly emphasize the amalgamation history of the various terranes. This proposal focuses on the syn- to post-collisional exhumation history of the deeper domains, as well as late-stage collapse of the mountain belt, to gain fundamental insights into late- to post-mountain formation processes in the northern Appalachians and beyond. Research is carried out in the southeastern New England section of the Appalachians through a strongly integrated research and educational plan.

The southeastern New England Appalachians generally consist of three terranes. From west to east they are the Merrimack, Nashoba and Avalon terranes. The Nashoba terrane is bounded by moderately NW-dipping faults. Preliminary field data suggest that deeper domains within the Nashoba terrane may have extruded towards the east, based on fold geometries, metamorphic characteristics and the apparent relationship between approximately 395 million year melts in the Nashoba terrane and approximately 395 million year intrusions in the structurally overlying Merrimack terrane. Furthermore, preliminary field observations indicate that most inter- and intra-terrane shear zones show evidence for late low-grade normal movement, presumably related to late-stage mountain collapse. The purpose of this research is to investigate both the high-temperature and low-temperature exhumation and collapse mechanisms through a combination of field mapping, detailed structural analysis and cutting-edge radiometric dating techniques.

Integration of research and field work into the undergraduate student experience is central to this project. Students from various geoscience departments in the Boston area are encouraged to participate and collaborate through a Geological Field Research course, giving them an excellent opportunity to discuss research with their peers and creating a stronger community. Subsequent thesis research by undergraduate and MS students involves analytical work at Boston College, MIT and UMass Amherst, strengthening the relationship between the three labs and between students and faculty. Students, especially women and minority students, are encouraged to participate through existing courses, departmental advising activities and other geoscience departments. Students from underrepresented groups are reached through the Boston College AHANA (African-American, Hispanic, Asian and Native American) student office and the McNair program for undergraduates who are low-income and first-generation college participants, and/or part of underrepresented groups.

Funding for this project is provided by the NSF EAR Tectonics Program, with support from the NSF EAR EarthScope and Education and Human Resources Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main scientific goal was to investigate the exhumation of middle to deep levels of ancient continental crust, and the collapse of the Appalachian mountain belt in southeastern New England, USA. Mechanisms of exhumation were investigated through detailed structural analysis of key areas coupled with cutting-edge techniques for dating deformation.

The Nashoba terrane in eastern Massachusetts formed about half a billion years ago as a volcanic arc and a back-arc sedimentary basin along the margin of a superterrane called Ganderia. The Nashoba terrane lies between the Merrimack belt to the northwest, a sedimentary basin that was deposited on top of Ganderian crust, and Avalonia to the southeast. Half a billion years ago, both Ganderia and Avalonia were part of supercontinent Gondwana that existed near the south pole. Since then, Ganderia and Avalonia rifted from Gondwana and became part of what is now North America during the ‘Salinic’ (~440-420 million years ago) and ‘Acadian’ (~420-360 million years ago) mountain building events, respectively. These events are part of the larger Appalachian mountain building event. During accretion, the Nashoba terrane was brought down to deeper levels in the crust, and experienced higher temperatures and pressures, than the adjacent Merrimack belt and Avalonia. In addition, it cooled earlier than the adjacent domains, suggesting it was exhumed earlier and faster. The new data suggest that early exhumation occurred towards the end of, and after the Acadian mountain building event. Early exhumation involved extrusion of a hot and weak Nashoba terrane between the cooler Merrimack belt and Avalonia. Later exhumation occurred along localized fault and shear zones. Movement along these may have started during or after the Acadian mountain building event.

Research conducted as part of this project also led to further thinking about why, towards the end of the Acadian mountain building event, convergence and exhumation as described above was still ongoing in eastern Massachusetts, while in Maine, a transition had occurred from a convergent setting towards a strike-slip setting. Strike-slip movement occurred along the Norumbega fault system, which was a crustal-scale fault, similar in scale and style to the modern San Andreas fault system. Likewise, eastern Massachusetts at that time occurred in a setting similar to the modern Cascades. The implications are that processes that shape the western USA today also shaped the northeastern US in the past. What is currently exposed at the surface in the northeastern USA, was at mid-crustal levels when these processes described above occurred. Thus rocks exposed in the northeastern USA can serve as an analog for what happens today in the middle crust in the western USA.

Several graduate and undergraduate students contributed to this project, and gained invaluable experience conducting field work, working in various analytical laboratories, and presenting at conferences. In addition, the project included development of a Geological Field Research Course for graduate and advanced undergraduate students, where students learn to design and conduct their own field research projects. Course goals were to gain experience in: (1) geological mapping, (2) independent field research, (3) hypothesis testing, (4) data presentation, (5) leadership skills, and (6) collaboration. Graduate and undergraduate students from the Colorado School of Mines, Boston College and Colorado College benefited from this course in 2012, 2014 and 2016. They gained experience not only in conducting field research, but also in designing research, writing and reviewing proposals and in writing a professional report including a geological map, cross and analysis of structural field data. A similar course is now part of the curriculum at the Colorado School of Mines.
